article.title: A search for passive protoplanetary disks in the Taurus-Auriga star-forming region

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the dashed line in the left panel of Figure 1 represent?
choices: The threshold for separating accreting from non-accreting T Tauri stars based on Hα EW.
The threshold for separating Class II and Class III objects based on the slope of the SED.
The median Hα EW for all objects in the sample.
The average Hα EW for accreting objects.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which subsample is represented by green circles in both panels of Figure 1?
choices: Candidate passive disks.
Borderline objects.
Accreting TTS control sample.
Disk-less objects.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be concluded from the right panel of Figure 1 regarding the sample selection?
choices: Most candidate passive disks have a significant infrared excess.
The spectral type distribution of the sample is representative of the Taurus population.
Both A and B are correct.
None of the above are correct.

multiple_choice_question.text: Why do some targets lack a data point in the right panel of Figure 1?
choices: These targets have no measurable Hα EW.
Their spectral type could not be determined.
They lack sufficient Spitzer photometry to determine the SED slope.
They are all members of multiple systems with blended photometry.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 3 illustrate?
choices: The difference between the true and measured Hα W10% values as a function of spectral resolution.
The relationship between Hα EW and W10% for accreting TTS.
The accuracy of the EW measurements as a function of spectral type.
The bias introduced on the Hα W10% estimates due to limited spectral resolution and sampling.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which type of Hα emission line is most susceptible to bias in the W10% measurement?
choices: Strong and narrow lines.
Weak and broad lines.
Weak and narrow lines.
The bias is independent of line strength and width.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the effect of spectral type on the bias and uncertainty of the W10% measurement for weak, narrow lines?
choices: The bias and uncertainty are both increased for later spectral types.
The bias is decreased, and the uncertainty is increased for later spectral types.
The bias is increased, and the uncertainty is decreased for later spectral types.
The bias and uncertainty are both decreased for later spectral types.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be concluded from the simulations regarding the impact of the instrumental resolution on the W10% measurement?
choices: Lower resolution spectra result in larger uncertainties and less constraining upper limits.
The bias introduced by the instrumental resolution is negligible for broad emission lines.
Both A and B are correct.
None of the above are correct.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main finding of Figure 5 regarding the variability of Hα EW?
choices: Accreting TTS display a significantly wider range of variability in Hα EW than non-accreting TTS.
Non-accreting TTS show no variability in Hα EW.
Disk-less objects display a similar range of variability in Hα EW as accreting TTS.
The amplitude of variability in Hα EW is independent of timescale.

multiple_choice_question.text: On which timescales is the difference in Hα EW variability amplitude between accretors and non-accretors statistically significant?
choices: Timescales longer than 1 month.
Timescales longer than 1 week.
Timescales longer than 1 day.
All of the above.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be said about the variability of W10% for accreting TTS?
choices: The amplitude of variations in W10% can be large, exceeding 150 km/s over all timescales.
A gradual increase in median W10% difference is observed with longer timescale.
Both A and B are correct.
None of the above are correct.

multiple_choice_question.text: Why is the analysis of W10% variability limited to accreting TTS in Figure 5?
choices: Non-accreting TTS and disk-less objects show no variability in W10%.
Insufficient W10% measurements were obtained for non-accreting and disk-less objects.
The W10% measurements for non-accreting and disk-less objects are too uncertain.
The W10% measurement is not a reliable indicator of accretion for non-accreting objects.

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of object is represented by the gray spectrum in both panels of Figure 7?
choices: A median Taurus Class II source.
A 3200 K NextGen stellar model.
A typical transition disk.
A debris disk.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main characteristic of the SEDs of the non-accreting disk-bearing objects in the left panel?
choices: They lack a significant infrared excess.
They show a pronounced double-hump shape.
They have strong near-infrared excess but weak mid-infrared excess.
They have a similar shape to the median Taurus Class II source.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which object in the right panel is an example of an "infrared companion"?
choices: FW Tau.
CZ Tau.
V819 Tau.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be concluded from Figure 7 regarding the accretion status of objects with disks extending to the immediate vicinity of the star?
choices: They are always accreting.
They are never accreting.
Their accretion status is highly variable.
Their accretion status cannot be determined from their SED.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main purpose of Figure 9?
choices: To show the temporal variability of Hα EW and W10% for individual accreting TTS.
To compare the Hα EW and W10% measurements from this study with those from Costigan et al. (2012).
To investigate the correlation between Hα EW and W10% for accreting TTS.
To illustrate the effects of self-absorption on the Hα line profile.

multiple_choice_question.text: What normalization is applied to the Hα EW and W10% measurements in Figure 9?
choices: They are normalized by the maximum value for each target.
They are normalized by the minimum value for each target.
They are normalized by the weighted average value for each target.
No normalization is applied.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main finding of Figure 9 regarding the relationship between Hα EW and W10%?
choices: There is no correlation between the two quantities.
A strong positive correlation exists between the two quantities.
A weak negative correlation exists between the two quantities.
The correlation between the two quantities is highly object-dependent.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the implication of the positive correlation between Hα EW and W10% for the accretion process?
choices: It suggests that changes in the accretion rate are directly responsible for changes in W10%.
It indicates that self-absorption plays a major role in shaping the Hα line profile.
It confirms that free-fall velocity is the main driver of the Hα linewidth.
It implies that chromospheric activity is the dominant source of Hα emission in accreting TTS.
